nodeMetric.field_description: The Cost Of Goods Sold (COGS) is the measure of costs incurred by a company to manufacture or resell a product. Costs typically include raw material and direct labour, but this varies from business to business, depending on the products or services that are being sold. COGS is the building block to understanding Gross Margin and Gross Margin Percent.
field_formula: Sum(Raw Material Costs + Direct Labour Costs)

body.processed:
For software companies, Cost Of Goods Sold (COGS) can include, for example, hosting fees, third party licensing fees, credit card processing fees, customer onboarding fees, and support costs.

For a company with a physical product, COGS for a given time period is calculated by adding the inventory left over from the last period and any new purchases, then subtracting the inventory left over at the end of the period.

COGS is an important financial metric that helps the business and its investors and analysts track performance and understand the bottom line. It is tracked as a business expense and is subtracted from a company’s revenue to get Gross Margin. Typically companies try to reduce their COGS over time. This can often be done through economies of scale.
body.summary: The Cost of Goods Sold (COGS), sometimes referred to as Cost of Sales, is the measure of costs incurred by a company to manufacture or resell a product in a defined time period. Costs typically include raw material and direct labour.

field_related_metrics.field_description: Revenue is the income generated through a business' primary operations, such as the sale of products or services, or proceeds from rent or interest, less any discounts or returns.

Net Income is an accounting term that refers to the total revenue minus the total expenses for any given period. Net Income is one of the best ways to determine a business' profitability and is often referred to as the bottom line. 

For Net Income, expenses to be deducted include Cost of Goods Sold (COGS), all operating expenses, and tax and interest costs.

Net Profit is the value that remains after all operating expenses are subtracted from a company’s revenue. Net Profit is one of the best ways to determine a business' profitability and is often referred to as the bottom line. 

For Net Income, expenses to be deducted include Cost of Goods Sold (COGS), all operating expenses, and tax and interest costs.
